DOCNAME: CASE OF ÜMIT GÜL v. TURKEY
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Substantive aspect);Violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Procedural aspect);Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial
JUDGES: András Sajó;Françoise Tulkens;Ireneu Cabral Barreto;Nona Tsotsoria;Vladimiro Zagrebelsky
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE police officers from the anti - terrorist branch of the NORP police headquarters arrested the applicant on suspicion of having written slogans on a wall in support of ORG , namely , ORG of GPE / Marxist NORP - Marxist ORG of GPE ( ORG PERSON ) , an illegal organisation . He was placed in police custody . According to the arrest report of DATE , the applicant did not ask for a lawyer .

CARDINAL . The applicant alleged that while in police custody he had been subjected to physical and psychological ill - treatment amounting to torture . The illtreatment consisted of , inter alia , being hosed with pressurised cold water and suspended by the arms , electric shocks and beatings .

CARDINAL . According to CARDINAL medical reports drawn up on CARDINAL , DATE , DATE and DATE by a doctor at ORG , apparently at the request of the police headquarters where the applicant was being detained , there were MONEY of ill - treatment on the applicant ’s body . It was stated in the reports that the applicant “ did not have any complaints , appeared well and was conscious ” and that there were “ no injuries on his body ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE , while he was in police custody , police officers questioned the applicant and recorded his statement . In the ninepage statement the applicant was reported as having stated that he did not want the assistance of a lawyer and went on to detail the activities he had carried out on behalf of the above - mentioned illegal organisation . These activities included distributing copies of a left - wing newspaper , writing slogans on walls and taking part in meetings with other members of the organisation .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was brought before the NORP prosecutor and subsequently before ORG ( Tunceli Sulh Ceza Mahkemesi ) , where he was questioned further . The applicant confirmed the accuracy of the contents of the statement he had made in police custody on DATE . ORG ordered the applicant ’s detention pending the outcome of the criminal proceedings . The applicant was detained in ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted a petition to ORG , requesting his release . In his petition the applicant stated that , in the course of his detention in police custody he had been subjected to intensive physical and psychological torture in order to force him to sign a statement . Furthermore , he had not been allowed to sleep for DATE preceding his appearance before the prosecutor and , as a result , had not been fully conscious when questioned . The applicant ’s request for release was rejected the following day .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant asked , in writing , for the ORG public prosecutor to refer him to a hospital so that MONEY left on his shoulders by the illtreatment could be documented . On DATE the ORG prosecutor decided that the alleged ill - treatment had not taken place in his area of jurisdiction and forwarded the applicant ’s letter to the NORP prosecutor .

CARDINAL . Following a request apparently made by the director of ORG on DATE , the applicant was examined on DATE by the director of the ORG branch of ORG , who is also a medical consultant . According to the report drawn up by that doctor , there were CARDINAL scars , measuring DATE by QUANTITY , on the front and back of the applicant ’s shoulders . It also appears from the report that the applicant had complained to the doctor about pain and restriction of movement in his arms . The doctor recommended that the applicant be sent to a fully equipped hospital for further diagnosis of his injuries and complaints .

CARDINAL . On DATE , and subsequently on DATE , the applicant made CARDINAL statements before a prosecutor and set out in detail the illtreatment to which he had been subjected by CARDINAL or QUANTITY police officers while in custody . According to these statements , the ill - treatment included being stripped naked and wrapped in a damp blanket before being beaten with truncheons and suspended by the arms , which caused the ligaments in his shoulders to tear . The police officers had also threatened to harm his relatives and get his father dismissed from his job as a neighbourhood security guard if he denied the allegations against him . The applicant told the prosecutor that the contents of the medical report drawn up by the NORP branch of ORG were correct and informed the prosecutor that he would be able to recognise the police officers responsible for the ill - treatment if he ever saw them again . He asked the prosecutor to prosecute them .

CARDINAL . The applicant was examined by a consultant orthopaedist and a consultant neurologist at ORG on DATE . The orthopaedist noted a number of scars on the applicant ’s shoulders , compatible with the findings of the medical report of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . The neurologist recommended the applicant ’s referral to a specialist hospital .

CARDINAL . On DATE the NORP prosecutor requested authorisation from the NORP governor to prosecute the police officers allegedly responsible for the applicant ’s ill - treatment . This request was made pursuant to LAW . DATE on ORG and other ORG .
CARDINAL . The applicant was released on bail on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE police chief PERSON , who was entrusted with the duty of investigating the applicant ’s allegations , questioned CARDINAL police officers , GPE and GPE , who had apparently questioned the applicant and taken down his statement on DATE . Both officers denied ill - treating the applicant and stated that “ members of terrorist organisations made such allegations in order to lower the morale of the police ” .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the NORP prosecutor referred the applicant to ORG in the city of ORG ( hereinafter “ ORG ” ) in order to establish whether the applicant ’s injuries had caused any permanent damage . A medical examination was scheduled to take place on DATE .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the police chief PERSON recommended to the NORP governor that permission for the prosecution of the CARDINAL police officers should not be granted .

CARDINAL . NORP The NORP prosecutor ’s request for authorisation to prosecute was refused by the NORP governor on DATE . The governor considered , on the basis of a report prepared by the police chief PERSON , that , other than the applicant ’s own allegations , there was no evidence to prove that the injuries detailed in the medical reports had been caused in detention .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an objection against the NORP governor ’s decision of CARDINAL DATE and argued that the decision , which had been taken before his examination at ORG was due , had failed to establish the truth and should be annulled .

CARDINAL . In its decision of DATE , ORG annulled the decision of the NORP governor on the ground that it was based on an incomplete investigation . In particular , the governor ’s decision had been taken before a detailed medical report from ORG had become available . Furthermore , the decision was based on a report prepared by an investigator who had not interviewed the applicant . Finally , the authorisation to prosecute had been rejected solely on the basis of the statements taken from those allegedly responsible for the ill - treatment and the medical reports drawn up while the applicant was in detention .
CARDINAL . On DATE Elazığ Hospital sent a letter to the NORP prosecutor informing him that the applicant “ did not have his ORG examination done ” .

CARDINAL . The same police chief PERSON was entrusted with the duty of carrying out the new investigation . When he questioned the applicant on DATE the applicant told him that when he had been brought before the doctor while in police custody he had been very scared and therefore had not been able to tell the doctor anything about the ill - treatment . In any event , the doctor had not examined him properly . When he had finally been referred to ORG he had been asked to pay the costs of the medical examination but had been unable to afford it . As a result , the doctors at the hospital had refused to examine him . The applicant told the police chief that he wanted those responsible for his ill - treatment to be prosecuted .
CARDINAL . NORP The police chief PERSON prepared his report on DATE and stated that in his opinion permission for the prosecution of the police officers should not be granted .

CARDINAL . On DATE the NORP governor again refused authorisation to prosecute the police officers . The governor noted the applicant ’s claim that he had not been examined at ORG as he had been unable to pay the cost ( MONEY ) for an electromyography test ( an ORG ) . The NORP governor considered that the defects highlighted in ORG decision of DATE had been eliminated and that there was no evidence that the applicant had been subjected to ill - treatment . The report of CARDINAL DATE , showing injuries on the applicant ’s body , had been obtained DATE after his release from police custody .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , the NORP governor ’s decision was not communicated to him , as in the meantime he had fled GPE and settled in GPE as a result of harassment to which police officers had subjected him . He did not , therefore , lodge an objection against this decision . According to a document submitted to ORG , however , the applicant was served with the decision on DATE .

CARDINAL . An automatic appeal was lodged against the NORP governor ’s decision with ORG , which , however , remitted it to the governor ’s office as only the applicant or the prosecutor could have lodged the appeal . ORG observed that the decision in question had become final as no appeal had been lodged .

CARDINAL . On the basis of the NORP governor ’s decision of DATE , on DATE the NORP prosecutor rendered a decision not to prosecute the police officers allegedly responsible for the ill - treatment . The applicant lodged an objection , through his legal representative , against that decision and pointed to the failure to remedy the defects identified in ORG decision of DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s objection was rejected by ORG on the basis of the NORP governor ’s above - mentioned decision of DATE .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , on DATE the prosecutor at ORG filed an indictment charging the applicant with the offences of membership of an illegal organisation and aiding and abetting members of that organisation . In his indictment the prosecutor quoted extensive paragraphs from the statements taken from the applicant by police officers on DATE and then by the prosecutor and ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . Criminal proceedings commenced before ORG of ORG ( hereinafter “ the trial court ” ) . In the course of the proceedings the applicant was represented by a lawyer . The applicant told the trial court that his statement had been extracted under torture while he was in police custody . He repudiated the statement and maintained his innocence . The trial court had regard to the NORP prosecutor ’s decision of DATE not to prosecute the police officers .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was found guilty of the offence of aiding and abetting an illegal organisation , contrary to LAW , and sentenced to DATE and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment . In convicting the applicant the trial court had regard to the statements taken from the applicant by the police on DATE and by the prosecutor and ORG on DATE ( see , respectively , paragraphs CARDINAL above ) .
CARDINAL . The applicant ’s conviction was upheld by ORG on DATE .
